discussion.content:
A network technician is connecting two switches together. Which of the following protocols should the technician use to increase speed and fault tolerance?
A. SIP
B. BGP
C. LACP
D. LLDP

LACP is the most correct answer. Link Aggregation Control Protocol can combine multiple physical ports together to make a single local channel. It allows for both redundancy and load balancing.
SIP is incorrect; Session Initiation Protocol is for establishing multimedia connections and would have no impact on speed or fault tolerance.
BGP is incorrect; Border Gateway Protocol is meant for linking routers and would be inappropriate to resolve the needs outlined here.
LLDP is incorrect; Link Layer Discovery Protocol is used in local Ethernet networks for advertising device identity, capability, and neighbours, defined in 802.1AB. This would help organize network paths but do not increase speed or fault tolerance.

questions.question_text: A network technician is connecting two switches together. Which of the following protocols should the technician use to increase speed and fault tolerance?

discussion.content:
I did a quick search of each and came up with the below. This would make D the correct answer. Correct if wrong please!

Remote desktop gateway - Layer 7
Transport mode IPSec - Layer 3
SSH tunneling - Layer 7
TLS VPN - Layer 2

comments.content: how is TLS VPN layer 2? TLS is 4+

discussion.content: IPSec would be acceptable if it was tunnel mode, but transport modes are made for client-to-server or host-to-host connections, it's not ideal for network to network. RDP is not used to connect networks, nor is SSH tunneling. Layer 2 network does not pertain to the technology used, it only asks that these networks be connected despite geographic separation.

This threw me for the first few times I read the question, but main difference between SSH and a VPN is SSH connects to an individual computer while a VPN connects to the network. The question states the various services/devices need to be configured on the network. So D, VPN would be the best answer to support the wording of the question.
D has to be correct, but wtf? It's not Layer 2, is it?
SSH tunneling and RDP is layer 7. IPsec is Layer 3 and the only remained option is TLS VPN
Passleader shows the answer to this as being 'B' Transport mod IPSec

SSH could be used just as well to connect directly to a remote printer, however, I think the key here is "The new devices need to be configured on the same Layer 2 network as the main office". VPN emulates direct network access that where SSH will not. Bastards...

questions.question_text: A company recently completed construction of a new remote office. The network administrator needs to set up new network devices, such as printers and a local file server, at the remote location. The new devices need to be configured on the same Layer 2 network as the main office. Which of the following should the network administrator configure?

An organization wants to implement a method of centrally managing logins to network services. Which of the following protocols should the organization use to allow for authentication, authorization, and auditing?

comments.content:
"Once the idea of AAA took shape, those smart Internet folks developed two standards: RADIUS and TACACS+. Both standards offer authentication, authorization, and accounting. RADIUS is the better known of two AAA standards."
- Page 372, Network+, Mike Meyers

According to the book, you'll even see "AAA/RADIUS" as they go together.
LDAP is your lightweight directory access protocol, secured or not, it will not and should not be used for authentication. RADIUS is primarily used for authentication.

discussion.content: What makes this answer Radius rather than LDAPS. I am not picking up on the key words or subtext that make this distinction in this question

Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) is a Microsoft proprietary protocol that enables remote connections to other computers, typically over TCP port 3389. It provides network access for a remote user over an encrypted channel.

questions.question_text: Ann, a network technician, set up a new server and enabled the host-based firewall. She attempts to connect to the server from several different workstations using RDP but is not successful. Which of the following ports on the firewall should she verify is open?

A network administrator is setting up a wireless network with poor security for a computer science class to hack. Which of the following security methods would be
MOST easily circumvented?

discussion.content: imo should be A, mac filtering is technically not security def. less than a shared key.

comments.content:
It's easier to get a shared key than to spoof a MAC. CompTIA agrees.
Most end users write their passwords down, the staff at my organization will write passwords on sticky notes and place them on their monitors for anyone to see.

I kinda agree. Unless the question does not consider MAC Filtering a "Security method". A shared key would at least provide some level of protection as you'd have to crack it, even on WPA, but if you are relying on just MAC Filtering, you could simply spoof the MAC.
